I see you consider death distant, while Allah sees it near. Do you not know that everything coming is near, and the distant is what is not coming? Do you not know that death comes suddenly, without sending a messenger, without appointment or agreement, and that it does not come in one thing without another, nor in winter without summer, nor in summer without winter, nor in day without night, nor in night without day, nor does it come in childhood without youth, nor in youth without childhood? They are five: The first: That he knows that Allah, the Exalted and Majestic, obligated the spending of the Zakat to him to suffice his concern and make his concerns a single concern. Indeed, Allah, the Exalted and Majestic, has obligated worship upon the creation that their concern be one, which is Allah, the Glorified, and the Last Day. This is what is meant by His saying, the Exalted: 'And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me.' But since wisdom necessitated that desires (Shahawat) and needs (Hajat) be given authority over the servant, and they disperse his concern, generosity necessitated the outpouring of a blessing that suffices the needs. So He multiplied wealth and poured it into the hands of His servants to be a tool for them in repelling their needs and a means for their free time for their acts of obedience (Taa'at). Among them are those whose wealth became a trial (Fitnah) and calamity (Baliyah), plunging him into danger. Among them are those whom He loved, so He protected him from the world (Dunya) just as the compassionate one protects his patient, so He withheld from him its excesses and directed to him the measure of his need through the hands of the wealthy, so that earning and the toil in gathering and preserving it would be easy upon them, and its benefit flows to the poor, so they become devoted to the worship (Ibadah) of Allah and preparation for what is after death. Thus, the excesses of the world do not divert them from it, nor do they distract them from preparing for poverty (Faqah). And this is the utmost blessing. So it is the right of the poor person to recognize the measure of the blessing of poverty and to realize that Allah's favor upon him in what He withheld from him is greater than His favor in what He gave him, as will come in the Book of Poverty its verification and clarification, if Allah wills. So let him take what he takes from Allah, the Glorified, as provision (Rizq) for him and as aid for him upon obedience (Taa'ah). And let his intention (Niyyah) in it be that he strengthens himself with it upon the obedience (Taa'ah) of Allah. If he is not capable of that, then let him spend it on what Allah, the Exalted and Majestic, has permitted. If he uses it as aid upon disobedience (Ma'siyah) to Allah, then he is ungrateful for the blessings of Allah, the Exalted and Majestic, deserving of distance and wrath from Allah, the Glorified.

Indeed, then, whoever employs a thing in a direction other than the direction for which it was created, and not in the manner intended for it, has indeed disbelieved in the blessing [ni'mah] of Allah, the Most High. So, whoever strikes another with his hand has disbelieved in the blessing of the hand, for the hand was created for him to repel with it from himself what would destroy him and to take what benefits him, not to destroy another with it. And whoever looks at the face of one who is not forbidden has disbelieved in the blessing of the eye and the blessing of the sun, for sight is perfected by them, and they were only created so that one may see with them what benefits him in his religion [din] and his worldly life [dunya], and to guard with them against what harms him in both. Thus, he has employed them in other than what was intended for them. And this is because the intended purpose from the creation of creation and the creation of the world [dunya] and its means is that creation may be aided by them to reach Allah, the Most High. And there is no reaching Him except through love [mahabbah] for Him and intimacy [uns] with Him in the world [dunya], and turning away from the deception of the world [dunya]. And there is no intimacy [uns] except through perpetual remembrance [dhikr], and no love [mahabbah] except through the knowledge [ma'rifah] attained through perpetual reflection [fikr]. And one cannot persist in remembrance [dhikr] and reflection [fikr] except through the persistence of the body [badan]. And the body [badan] does not remain except through nourishment [ghidha'], and nourishment [ghidha'] is not perfected except through the earth, water, and air. And that is not perfected except through the creation of the heaven and the earth, and the creation of all the limbs, outwardly and inwardly. So all of that is for the sake of the body [badan], and the body [badan] is the mount of the soul [nafs]. And what returns to Allah, the Most High, is the soul at peace [al-nafs al-mutma'innah] through prolonged worship ['ibadah] and knowledge [ma'rifah].
